Award.AwardTitle: Roll-To-Roll Electrostatic Printing for Manufacturing Few-Layer-Graphenes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to develop roller-based electrostatic printing systems for massively producing pristine, orderly arranged few-layer-graphene structures for scale-up applications in electronics and optoelectronics. The primary research objectives are to (i) experimentally study roll-to-roll and roll-to-plate electrostatic transfer-printing processes, aiming to enable the continuous production of device patterns of few-layer-graphenes on inch-scale wide substrates with a high throughput; (ii) obtain an in-depth understanding of underlying scientific mechanisms associated with the precise exfoliation of atomically layered structures of van der Waals solids through the modeling of roll-to-roll processes using dynamic simulation tools; (iii) quantitatively identify the effects of key processing parameters, such as printing pressure, electric strength, and roller speed on the final printing quality in terms of transfer efficiency, uniformity of graphene thickness over substrates, density of defects, and electrical properties of printed graphenes; and (iv) explore the novel application of electrostatic printing in the fabrication of graphene-based optical devices.

The successful completion of this work will broadly contribute fundamental knowledge in the areas of high-speed manufacturing technologies and significantly expand the capability to process emerging atomically layered materials. It is anticipated that the proposed roll-to-roll electrostatic printing techniques, if successfully realized, will surpass the capability of current technologies for producing few-layer-graphenes in terms of a high degree of material crystallinity comparable to that of the best crystal graphite, a high degree of simplicity for realizing multi-scale patterning, a high roll-to-roll throughput > 50 ft/min, and a low patterning cost less than $2/m2. It also holds the significant potential to be developed into cost-effective, environment-friendly industrial manufacturing processes that can address global needs for addressing future energy needs and US industrial competitiveness. In addition, the program will provide new education and outreach opportunities for involving K-12 students and underrepresented undergraduates into manufacturing-related research activities.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project sought to create new materials processing technologies enabling the mass production of emerging 2D layered materials as well as functional device arrays. In addition, the project also aimed at advancing the understanding of the unique structural, electronic, and photonic properties of layered materials, which is critical for ultimately realizing the scale-up applications of these materials. Since the initiation of the project three years ago, the research team has made significant breakthroughs in developing new roller-based printing/imprinting technologies for producing layered material/structure arrays and demonstrating a series of electronic/photonic devices. Specifically, the research project has resulted in the following outcomes. (1) Invented and demonstrated a new electrostatic printing method/system for producing few-layer graphene and other 2D layered nanomaterials over large areas. This new printing approach employs plasma-assisted processes for generating uniform surface charges over the dielectric layers coated onto the target substrates, which can effectively exfoliate/immobilize prepatterned material pixels (Fig. 1). (2) Constructed and investigated a roll-to-roll electrostatic nanoprinting system for producing large arrays of 2D layered materials. Specifically, the team has built a roller system capable of generating a uniform printing pressure between templates and substrates. Furthermore, based on this system, the team has invented and incorporated a new nanoimprint-assisted shear exfoliation (NASE) module capable of generating few-layer MoS2 and graphene flakes with uniform thicknesses and electronic properties (Fig. 2). (3) Invented a new post-printing plasma-assisted doping process that can modulate the transport properties of as-printed 2D layers (Fig. 3). (4) Significantly extended the device applications of created roll-to-roll/roll-to-plate printing processes, NASE technology, as well as post-printing plasma doping processes in nanoelectronics, optoelectronics, and biosensing devices. A series of functional devices have been produced and characterized, which include graphene/MoS2-based photovoltaic (PV) diode devices exhibiting very high quantum efficiencies over a broad range of wavelengths (Fig. 4a), MoS2-based thin-film transistor arrays as well as multiple transistor biosensors with unprecedented sensitivity and detection limit (Fig. 4b), and multi-channel power-switching field-effect transistor (FET) arrays using densely aligned 8 nm-half-pitch graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) as the active channels (Fig. 4c). Such GNRs were produced using a post-printing lithographic technique developed by the PI, which is able to pattern as-printed few-layer-graphene films into semiconducting GNRs with tunable ribbon widths and pitches (8 to 50 nm). (5) Created new molecular dynamics (MD) modeling tools for studying the exfoliation of patterned nanometer-sized graphite under various normal loading conditions for friction-induced exfoliation (see Fig. 2), which has significantly advanced the understanding of the nanoscopic mechanical mechanisms associated with the precise exfoliation of nanoscale layers.

Intellectual Merits:  This NSF-funded project has resulted in a transformative impact on the development of new top-down manufacturing approaches for producing functional material/device arrays based on emerging 2D-layered materials (graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, and topological insulators), and also significantly advanced the scientific knowledge required for bridging the technical gap between the fundamental research and mass production of 2D-layered materials and structures. The fundamental science associated with the precise exfoliation of atomically thin electronic material patterns with uniform thicknesses and electronic/photonic properti...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF-funded project sought to create new materials processing technologies enabling the mass production of emerging 2D layered materials as well as functional device arrays. In addition, the project also aimed at advancing the understanding of the unique structural, electronic, and photonic properties of layered materials, which is critical for ultimately realizing the scale-up applications of these materials. Since the initiation of the project three years ago, the research team has made significant breakthroughs in developing new roller-based printing/imprinting technologies for producing layered material/structure arrays and demonstrating a series of electronic/photonic devices. (1) Invented and demonstrated a new electrostatic printing method/system for producing few-layer graphene and other 2D layered nanomaterials over large areas. This new printing approach employs plasma-assisted processes for generating uniform surface charges over the dielectric layers coated onto the target substrates, which can effectively exfoliate/immobilize prepatterned material pixels (Fig. 1). (2) Constructed and investigated a roll-to-roll electrostatic nanoprinting system for producing large arrays of 2D layered materials. Specifically, the team has built a roller system capable of generating a uniform printing pressure between templates and substrates. Furthermore, based on this system, the team has invented and incorporated a new nanoimprint-assisted shear exfoliation (NASE) module capable of generating few-layer MoS2 and graphene flakes with uniform thicknesses and electronic properties (Fig. 2). A series of functional devices have been produced and characterized, which include graphene/MoS2-based photovoltaic (PV) diode devices exhibiting very high quantum efficiencies over a broad range of wavelengths (Fig. 4a), MoS2-based thin-film transistor arrays as well as multiple transistor biosensors with unprecedented sensitivity and detection limit (Fig. 4b), and multi-channel power-switching field-effect transistor (FET) arrays using densely aligned 8 nm-half-pitch graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) as the active channels (Fig. 4c). Such GNRs were produced using a post-printing lithographic technique developed by the PI, which is able to pattern as-printed few-layer-graphene films into semiconducting GNRs with tunable ribbon widths and pitches (8 to 50 nm). (5) Created new molecular dynamics (MD) modeling tools for studying the exfoliation of patterned nanometer-sized graphite under various normal loading conditions for friction-induced exfoliation (see Fig. 2), which has significantly advanced the understanding of the nanoscopic mechanical mechanisms associated with the precise exfoliation of nanoscale layers. Intellectual Merits: This NSF-funded project has resulted in a transformative impact on the development of new top-down manufacturing approaches for producing functional material/device arrays based on emerging 2D-layered materials (graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, and topological insulators), and also significantly advanced the scientific knowledge required for bridging the technical gap between the fundamental research and mass production of 2D-layered materials and structures. The fundamental science associated with the precise exfoliation of atomically thin electronic material patterns with uniform thicknesses and electronic/photonic properties has been systematically studied for further optimizing the manufacturing performance.
